A group of engineers are asked to design a very bright light bulb that is to be used on airport runways. The filament in the light bulb dissipates electrical energy as light and thermal energy. The engineers can choose filaments of varying thicknesses, lengths, and materials, and connect the bulb to a variable power supply, shown in the figure.

(a) A student correctly claims that for the same potential difference across the bulb, a greater current in the bulb corresponds to a greater amount of electrical energy dissipated by the bulb each second. Justify this claim in terms of charge.

(b) The lightbulb is tested with varying filaments made from the same material. The same potential difference is applied across the bulb for each trial. The filaments have the same lengths but varying thicknesses. The power dissipated by the bulb when the thinnest filament is used is <math alttext="P sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. The power dissipated by the bulb when the thickest filament is used is <math alttext="P sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. Is <math alttext="P sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> greater than, less than, or equal to <math alttext="P sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>? Justify your answer.

(c) The lightbulb is again tested with varying filaments. During these trials, the filaments are made of different materials but have the same lengths and thicknesses. Describe how the resistivity of the material may affect the power dissipated by the filament of the lightbulb. Justify your answer.

The engineers build a bulb with a filament of known length and thickness and wish to experimentally determine the filamentâ€™s resistivity. The engineers change the potential difference applied to the lightbulb and measure the current in the bulb with an ammeter.
<math alttext="voltage, in volts" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>V</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mo>(</mo><mtext>V</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math><math alttext="current, in amps" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>I</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mo>(</mo><mtext>A</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>120.05240.10500.201000.401200.50
(d) Which quantities (raw or calculated from the data above) would be plotted on the vertical and horizontal axes to produce a linear graph to determine the resistivity of the filament?
(e) Describe how the information from the graph from part (d) would be used to determine the resistivity of the filament.

(f) The engineers are told that the maximum potential difference that can be applied to the bulb cannot exceed <math alttext="200 volts" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>200</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>V</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and that the desired brightness at that voltage is obtained when the current in the bulb is <math alttext="1.0 amp" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Describe the modifications to the filament used in the experiment above that would meet the specifications given. Cite features of the data provided to support your claim.
